habitat_description:
Phalacrocorax pelagicus nests in sea caves (Carter et al., 1984; Speich and Wahl, 1989; Campbell et al., 1990; Chatwin et al., 2002) and on narrow ledges on steep cliffs (Jones, 1909; Cogswell, 1977; Manuwal and Campbell, 1979; Siegel-Causey and Hunt, 1981; Carter et al., 1984; Campbell et al., 1990; Chatwin et al., 2002). Occasionally, the species will nest on beached driftwood (Campbell et al., 1990) and man-made structures such as radio towers, pilings, and abandoned piers (Hobson and Wilson, 1985; Campbell et al., 1990; Hatch et al., 2011; Kotzerka et al., 2011). Diurnal roost sites are also on cliff ledges, in caves, on logs, and on man-made structures (Hobson and Sealy, 1986; Campbell et al., 1990; Hobson, 1997) but also include rocky promontories (Hobson and Sealy, 1986; Campbell et al., 1990), sandbars and spits (Hobson, 1997; Campbell et al., 1990), and unvegetated islets (Hobson and Sealy, 1986; Campbell et al., 1990). The species remains in close proximity to marine waters (Campbell et al., 1990; Hobson, 1997).

Pelagic cormorants forage in open water (Campbell et al., 1990; Kotzerka et al., 2011). In areas of sympatry with its congeners, the pelagic cormorant’s foraging is restricted to waters over rocky substrates (Ainley et al., 1981).
